author: melvlee
title: Cute Shuttle with a brick built nose and tail!
review:
As someone who remembers the excitement both leading up to and upon seeing the very first first shuttle launch back in 1981 (just 3 years after the release of Classic Space!), the Space Shuttle has always held a special place for me in the exploration of space.  And it's also great that despite the retirement of the real shuttles, Lego is still putting out shuttle sets as they seem perfect for space play.

Pros:

1. Nice stand-alone shuttle. The proportions are on the cute side but it works nicely with the minifig scale. The cockpit comes off easily to seat the minifig.

2. A brick built nose!! One of the reasons I passed up most of the recent Space Shuttle sets (3367, 60078, 60080, not counting the Shuttle Expedition sets which were too expensive for me anyway) was the juniorised one-piece nose. It's very interesting to see this brick-built nose come together during the build, and somewhat shocking to recognise the transparent cockpit window piece as coming from the windscreen of Speed Champions vehicles!.

3. A brick-built tail as well!

4. Cool little EVA suit for the spaceman minifig and good that we get a transparent visor to see his determined expression. Together with the satellite and robotic arm, it makes for some enjoyable spacewalk play.

Cons:

1. Appreciate that the rear engines are tilted in their triangular configuration using some neat technic techniques but viewed from some angles the engines look a bit silly and exposed as there is nothing to hide the thin technic connectors. I don't own 60080 Spaceport but the engines in that set look more satisfyingly solid.

2. The underside is a bit too flat for my liking. A few extra plates to give it a bit more underbelly volume would have been nice.

Overall, this is a great set for any space and space shuttle lovers. Pretty good value for money. (The alternative builds don't really attract me but I guess I'll get around to them some time later).

author: HikerCZ
title: Definitely not lost in space!
review:
I blame Saturn V for getting this set. With the news of the (absolutely stunning) Apollo 11 set my interest in the Space theme had been rebooted. I immediately started browsing through older space sets whetting my appetite to be ready for the 'big thing' later this year. I even considered getting the juniorised version of the space shuttle from the previous space themed city line. Luckily Lego was thinking along the same lines and managed to release a new set to make the Space theme even more exciting. 

Let me be perfectly honest with you. I enjoy the Creator line. I'm not a regular collector but every now and then I treat myself to an interesting set and I'm almost always positively surprised what I get for my money's worth. It's the same case here. I had seen the reviews before buying the shuttle but was surprised anyway. It's much nicer and larger than I'd expected. 27x19 cm (almost 1 ft) of a solid, straightforward build which is not flimsy and looks fine from almost every angle.

As it is a Creator set, some compromises had to be made. I agree with the previous reviewer that some sections may seem a little bit underwhelming (mostly in details) but the overall impression is good in my opinion. I mean we get a brick-built nose and tail which look so much better than their large prefabricated counterparts; the cargo bay is big enough to carry the satellite and the EVA suit. If you leave the satellite and the telescopic arm out, you can fit in a decent amount of cargo for your space missions or a nice crew of astronauts travelling to your space station. It's pretty swooshable, the only soft spot being where the curved pieces meet in the middle.

Accessories seem somewhat limited, you get a satellite, a wrench, one astronaut - who is slightly different from the previous city line (wait for the secondary facial expression, it's priceless!). However, if you own any space sets, you can add, accessorise to your heart's desire. It's both a good play set for the kids and a lovely display piece for AFOLs (especially if you add a small stand or wheels). 

I haven't tried the other builds, as my main focus was the shuttle. The station seems interesting enough though. I'd recommend building it first because once you build your shuttle, I doubt you'll be willing to disassemble it. That was definitely my case.

Well done Lego, this is what combining creativity and play should be about without jacking the price up.

author: Doogiemy2k
title: Space Shuttle Explorer
review:
I found this set a lot of fun. To find a creator set with a mini fig is a treat and this one was well worth it.

i enjoyed the 3 builds a lot and settled on the shuttle itself as the final build. I am however keeping my eyes open for more of this set to eventually do all three builds, or maybe just build a fleet of shuttles.

author: Oregondete81
title: Great Value Set
review:
This is a LEGO creator 3in1 set. You can build the shuttle, mining lab, and a surface vehicle and the set comes with one spaceman minifig. 

I was a huge fan of LEGO as a kid, but hadn't bought a set or played with LEGO in well over a decade. I was feeling a bit nostalgic so I went out and bought myself a LEGO set. This set was a great value, especially with the multiple building possibilities. This was the most fun I've had in awhile and this set was an amazing reintroduction. The shuttle is SO COOL! The vehicle was a lot of fun to build and left me with enough spare pieces to build a cool little attachment mine set-up. The mining lab was a cool scene as well. Overall for the value of this set, the playability, and the building options it was an Amazing set. If you are looking for an affordable option as a collector or parent I would highly recommend this set.
